title: The Weighty Truth About HIV Meds and Black Women

content: It's your favorite HIV+ blogger, back with a topic that hits close to home – weight gain after starting HIV meds. Buckle up, because we're diving deep into a conversation that many of us in the HIV community face but rarely talk about openly.
So grab a cup of tea, get comfy, and let's chat.

Weight gain after starting my HIV meds has been a major concern for me. Back in September 2016, when I received my diagnosis, I was the closest to my ideal weight that I'd been in my adult life. I was on a health kick, working out twice a day. I had a clean eating regimen that would make any nutritionist proud.
Life was good. I felt amazing in my own skin.

Then came my HIV diagnosis, and my introduction to HIV meds. Don't get me wrong. I'm incredibly grateful for the advancements in HIV treatment. These meds have given me the chance to live a healthy and fulfilling life.

content: But they came with a side effect I didn't expect – weight gain.

Since starting my meds, I've been on a roller-coaster ride trying to shed the extra 30 pounds stubbornly clinging to me. No matter how hard I tried, those pounds wouldn't budge. It's been frustrating, to say the least.
I found myself wondering, "Why is this happening? What's going on with my body?"

Studies show a rise in body weight for those living with HIV (PLWH) who start taking a certain type of HIV medication known as integrase strand transfer inhibitors (INSTIs). The details of why some experience weight gain on these meds are still a bit of a mystery, especially when it comes to women, girls, and racial/ethnic minorities.

This is where it gets personal. You see, when Black women start taking HIV meds, they may experience weight gain as a side effect. This can be a significant concern. We know excess weight can have negative impacts on our health and well-being. We've got enough on our plates (pun intended), and dealing with unexpected weight gain is an unwelcome guest crashing our party.

content: Let's talk about data for a moment.

One study discovered that Black women and girls who began using INSTI-based HIV medication regimens had a more significant average increase in body weight, when compared to those on PI-based regimens. On the other hand, Hispanic people using INSTI and PI regimens showed similar average weight increases, but those on INSTI regimens had a larger percentage with weight gains (5% or more).
In simpler terms, it means that Black women, like me, are more likely to experience weight gain when starting certain HIV meds.

This weight gain isn’t just about aesthetics. It's about how it makes us feel. I remember those days when I used to look in the mirror and feel so confident. Now, I sometimes struggle to recognize myself. That can take a toll on my self-esteem and mental health.
But here's the thing: I refuse to let these extra pounds define me or my journey. I'm more than a number on a scale. And you are too, my dear readers.

content: Living with HIV teaches me resilience, strength, and the importance of self-love.
So, what's the game plan? Well, first and foremost, more research is needed on the effects of HIV meds on Black women. We need a better understanding of why this happens, and how we can mitigate it.

I'm also focused on finding a balance that works for me. It's not about crash diets or punishing workouts anymore. It's about nourishing my body, staying active in ways I enjoy, and practicing self-compassion.
It's about realizing that my health is about more than just my weight.

As we look ahead, I hope science and medicine continue to evolve. Maybe there’ll be HIV meds in the future that don't come with this weighty side effect. Perhaps there’ll be more tailored treatments for different populations. One can hope, right?
In the meantime, I want you to know that you're not alone in this journey.

Whether you're living with HIV or facing other health challenges, remember you’re strong, beautiful, and resilient. Our bodies tell unique stories, and they're worth celebrating. Honor the body that you have. It’s the only one you get, and it’s literally carried you through every single aspect of your life.

Stay fabulous, Darlings. Never forget that you’re loved, just as you are.
